context: However, in English, the term madrasah usually refers to the specifically <a0_0><b5_0>Islamic institutions<b5_0/><a0_0/>. A typical Islamic school usually offers two courses of study: a ḥifẓ course teaching <a1_0><b6_0>memorization of the Qur'<b6_0/>an<a1_0/> (the person who commits the entire Qurʼan to memory is called a ḥāfiẓ); and an <a4_0>ʻālim<a4_0/> course leading the candidate to become an accepted scholar in the community. A regular curriculum includes courses in Arabic, tafsir (Qur'anic interpretation), sharīʻah (<a2_0><b7_0>Islamic law<b7_0/><a2_0/>), hadiths (recorded sayings and deeds of Muhammad), mantiq (<a3_0><b8_0>logic<b8_0/><a3_0/>), and Muslim history. In the Ottoman Empire, during the Early Modern Period, the study of hadiths was introduced by Süleyman I. Depending on the educational demands, some madaris also offer additional advanced courses in <b9_0>Arabic literature<b9_0/>, English and other foreign languages, as well as science and world history. Ottoman madaris along with religious teachings also taught "styles of writing, grammary, syntax, poetry, composition, natural sciences, political sciences, and etiquette."
